title: Cultural Amnesia: Notes in the Margin of My Time
review: The best prose on culture

title: Irrational Man: A Study in Existential Philosophy
author: William Barret
review: It's amazing how good a book on philosophy can be to read. After this book I finally recognized the fact that I have been an existentialist since childhood. In fact, I think Chinese people who have gone through atheism and post-modernization, as long as they are not staunch Marxists, all of them have more or less existentialist thoughts. But I still retain doubts. Existentialism still cannot calm me. For I have no religious fervor or desire for the will to power. The fear of death and the paradox of the value of life cannot be removed by my existentialism.

title: An Owner’s Guide to the Human Genome
author: Jonathan K Pritchard
review: The best genetics book ever. It's not out yet... I'm looking forward to the update.

title: Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking
author: Daniel C. Dennett
review: Read it too early .... I remember it being particularly useful, but I didn't read it very well. Plan to read it again.

title: Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!: Adventures of a Curious Character
review: Feynman is the man who discovered the true nature of science. Science should be played out, and it should be more fun than utilitarian. A scientist, we should resist the mystification, falsification, monopoly of knowledge behavior, away from the discovery of the fun of science will degenerate into a bureaucratic utilitarian things. Feynman's smooth sailing is really due to his integration of fun in learning, integration of thinking in life. So I think that in some places, like Brazil in the book, it is impossible to develop real science without a political, cultural and social context. The scientific endeavor in these places is developed at the expense of human happiness and the idea of freedom. When science becomes an instrument of the State, it is a disaster for the nation.

title: Illness as Metaphor and Aids and Its Metaphors
author: Susan Sontag
review:
I suddenly thought that 'disease' itself is a very special term. Disease is not a tangible entity; it is different from pathogens and symptoms, and it does not belong to the body. It is the cause of the state of being unhealthy. According to normal word formation logic, people would first name this state and then name the cause. For example, the state of being ill could be called 'non-health,' so disease should be called 'non-health cause.' However, people first refer to it as disease and then call the state of being ill, which indicates that the term 'disease' holds significant meaning for people.
Moreover, when people say they have recovered from an illness, there is also a logical contradiction, because recovering health should logically be called 'the illness has worsened.' This makes one feel that disease itself is an extremely ambiguous existence; it exists between the metaphysical and the physical, it is both self and enemy, arising from life yet oriented towards death. The term itself inevitably carries metaphorical implications. Susan Sontag said that the worst metaphor for disease is the military metaphor, which is very interesting in connection with today's article by Qin Hui.

title: Connectome: How the Brain’s Wiring Makes Us Who We Are
review: Six years ago, I read it and found it very captivating. Now, the connectome of the fruit fly has been released... I guess it can be considered witnessing a scientific breakthrough.

title: The Language Instinct
author: Steven Pinker
review: Got me interested in linguistics and psychology.

title: The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined
review: I've been reading it on and off for a month since I started learning how to drive before I finished it, and there's a lot of inspiring things about it. For example, read his power law respectively point of view to realize that the childhood was indoctrinated in the historical determinism of the wrong, the prisoner's dilemma extrapolated from the dilemma of pacifism is a very good thinking tool. The taper is the last few chapters, and social psychology should be Pinker's home turf now. Looking at the current situation with a rolling ladder of rationality would be a good way to give some direction in the fog and some optimistic soothing to the pessimistic.

title: Why Buddhism is TRUE
review: This book answers a question I've always had, which is whether or not Dzogchen experience/meditation/nirvana, and other such mystical experiences can be combined with science to give us a better life. There are many questions that science has not yet been able to answer, but that doesn't mean we have to stop thinking about them and wait for a scientific answer to come along that is absolutely right. For example, how to think about death, or what kind of lifestyle to choose. The book says that a way of thinking from the heart, meditation, can enhance our experience of life and is largely corroborated by science. It's a revelation to me that in these moments of uncertainty and grayness, there are ways to find inner peace in the pursuit of truth.

title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
author: Thomas S.Kuhn
review: A very important concept, but one that I don't think applies well to modern science.

label: popular science
review: Steven Pinker really is an unabashed optimist. Although his arguments are very restructured, it's hard to remain an optimist in these times for me. The first and last chapters are really good. (I read it in Chinese version)

title: The Sense of Style
author: Steven Pinker
label: writing
review: The book taught me writing skills, and also subverting my perceptions of language.

title: The Sense of Style
author: Steven Pinker

title: R in action
author: Robert I. Kabacoff
label: programming
review: This book taught me one thing: that English original textbooks may not be incomprehensible for non-native English speakers. A good textbook can definitely overcome language barriers.

title: Bioinfomatics Data Skills
author: Vince Buffalo
review: My first book to learn bioinfomatics. It's classic, and good for beginner.

title: R packages
author: Hadley Wickham
review: It is very simple and easy to understand, offering a clear and accessible approach. It is an essential read for anyone looking to write R packages. More importantly, it has helped me understand how to manage projects effectively.
